title: Supporting the wave model of matter

content.question: Electrons are accelerated through a potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and are then incident on a crystal. The resulting diffraction pattern is observed on a screen. If the potential difference is then decreased, the spacing between maxima of the diffraction pattern increases. Does this increase in spacing support the wave model of matter, and why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the lower <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> would yield a lower electron momentum, which would yield a shorter de Broglie wavelength, which would increase the spacing between maxima.

Yes, because the lower <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> would yield a lower electron momentum, which would yield a longer de Broglie wavelength, which would increase the spacing between maxima.
No, because the formation of a diffraction pattern is a particle phenomenon.
No, because if the electrons could be described as waves they could not interact with the crystal, which consists of particles.
